newsitem.title: USA: PRESS DIGEST - New York Times business - Jan 21.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - New York Times business - Jan 21.

text.p: The New York Times reported the following business stories Tuesday:
* Boston Scientific Corp agrees to acquire Target Therapeutics Inc in a stock swap valued at about $1.1 billion.
* PaineWebber Group Inc, Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette and Alex. Brown Inc report fourth quarter earnings that exceed analysts' expectations.
* The Dow Jones industrial average rises 10.77 points to close at 6,843.87 on strong earnings reports, especially in technology sector.
* Four Federal Reserve governors said during the past week that they would likely move quickly to raise interest rates if they see an acceleration in wages or prices later this year.
* Nasdaq begins trading 50 stocks under new rules that should provide better prices for the average investor.
* Strikes in South Korea end after more than three weeks. Business leaders say the economy should suffer little lasting effect.
* Italian information technology firm Ing C Olivetti & C SpA sells personal computer company to Piedmont International for $159 to $190 million.
* Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc Chief Executive John Zabriskie resigns.
* Netscape Communications Corp is expected to announce that the accounting firm of KPMG Peat Marwick has picked its newest business software for KMPG's 120 U.S. offices.
* Credit Foncier de France employees occupy the firm's headquarters to fight a plan to sell the company.
* Pepsi-Cola will alter its advertising with "Generation next theme."
* Airlines such as Delta Air Lines INc and UAL Corp are investing heavily in technology that helps them reroute flights hampered by bad weather.
* Dow Jones & Co Inc announces plans to spend $650 million to overhaul its financial information unit; its stock falls 10 percent.

* Banc One Corp agrees its $7.3 billion acquisition of First USA Inc is expensive, but says becoming the third largest credit card company in the United States will raise its earnings growth to 15 percent a year.
* The inventor of Eudora, an electronic mail software used by 18 million people, is neither rich nor famous.
